lines.value: FRANCISCO

lines.value: FRANCISCO
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: You come most carefully upon your hour.
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: FRANCISCO
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: For this relief much thanks: 'tis bitter cold,
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: And I am sick at heart.
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Have you had quiet guard?
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: FRANCISCO
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: Not a mouse stirring.
lines.speaker: FRANCISCO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus,

lines.value: The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: FRANCISCO

lines.value: FRANCISCO

lines.value: FRANCISCO

lines.value: Bernardo has my place.

lines.value: Give you good night.

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Holla! Bernardo!

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Say,
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: What, is Horatio there?
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO

lines.value: A piece of him.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Welcome, Horatio: welcome, good Marcellus.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: What, has this thing appear'd again to-night?
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: I have seen nothing.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: And will not let belief take hold of him
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us:
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Therefore I have entreated him along
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: With us to watch the minutes of this night;
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: That if again this apparition come,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: He may approve our eyes and speak to it.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Tush, tush, 'twill not appear.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Sit down awhile;
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: And let us once again assail your ears,
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: That are so fortified against our story
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: What we have two nights seen.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Well, sit we down,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And let us hear Bernardo speak of this.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Last night of all,
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: When yond same star that's westward from the pole
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Had made his course to illume that part of heaven
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself,
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: The bell then beating one,--
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Peace, break thee off; look, where it comes again!
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: In the same figure, like the king that's dead.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Thou art a scholar; speak to it, Horatio.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Looks it not like the king?  mark it, Horatio.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Most like: it harrows me with fear and wonder.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: It would be spoke to.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Question it, Horatio.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: What art thou that usurp'st this time of night,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Together with that fair and warlike form
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: In which the majesty of buried Denmark
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Did sometimes march? by heaven I charge thee, speak!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: It is offended.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: See, it stalks away!
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Stay! speak, speak! I charge thee, speak!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: 'Tis gone, and will not answer.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: How now, Horatio! you tremble and look pale:
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Is not this something more than fantasy?
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: What think you on't?
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Before my God, I might not this believe
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Without the sensible and true avouch
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Of mine own eyes.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Is it not like the king?
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: As thou art to thyself:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Such was the very armour he had on
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: When he the ambitious Norway combated;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: So frown'd he once, when, in an angry parle,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: 'Tis strange.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: In what particular thought to work I know not;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: But in the gross and scope of my opinion,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: This bodes some strange eruption to our state.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Good now, sit down, and tell me, he that knows,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Why this same strict and most observant watch
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: So nightly toils the subject of the land,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: And why such daily cast of brazen cannon,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: And foreign mart for implements of war;
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Why such impress of shipwrights, whose sore task
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Does not divide the Sunday from the week;
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: What might be toward, that this sweaty haste
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day:
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Who is't that can inform me?
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: That can I;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: At least, the whisper goes so. Our last king,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Whose image even but now appear'd to us,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Thereto prick'd on by a most emulate pride,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Dared to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet--
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: For so this side of our known world esteem'd him--
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal'd compact,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Well ratified by law and heraldry,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Which he stood seized of, to the conqueror:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Against the which, a moiety competent
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Was gaged by our king; which had return'd
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Had he been vanquisher; as, by the same covenant,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And carriage of the article design'd,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Of unimproved mettle hot and full,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Hath in the skirts of Norway here and there
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Shark'd up a list of lawless resolutes,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: For food and diet, to some enterprise
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: That hath a stomach in't; which is no other--
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: As it doth well appear unto our state--
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: But to recover of us, by strong hand
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: So by his father lost: and this, I take it,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Is the main motive of our preparations,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: The source of this our watch and the chief head
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Of this post-haste and romage in the land.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: I think it be no other but e'en so:
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Well may it sort that this portentous figure
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Comes armed through our watch; so like the king
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: That was and is the question of these wars.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: A mote it is to trouble the mind's eye.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: In the most high and palmy state of Rome,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: A little ere the mightiest Julius fell,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Disasters in the sun; and the moist star
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Upon whose influence Neptune's empire stands
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And even the like precurse of fierce events,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: As harbingers preceding still the fates
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And prologue to the omen coming on,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Have heaven and earth together demonstrated
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Unto our climatures and countrymen.--
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: But soft, behold! lo, where it comes again!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: I'll cross it, though it blast me. Stay, illusion!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: If thou hast any sound, or use of voice,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Speak to me:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: If there be any good thing to be done,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: That may to thee do ease and grace to me,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Speak to me:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: If thou art privy to thy country's fate,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Which, happily, foreknowing may avoid, O, speak!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Extorted treasure in the womb of earth,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Speak of it: stay, and speak! Stop it, Marcellus.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Shall I strike at it with my partisan?
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Do, if it will not stand.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: 'Tis here!
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: 'Tis here!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: 'Tis gone!
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: We do it wrong, being so majestical,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: To offer it the show of violence;
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: For it is, as the air, invulnerable,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: And our vain blows malicious mockery.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: It was about to speak, when the cock crew.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And then it started like a guilty thing
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Upon a fearful summons. I have heard,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: The cock, that is the trumpet to the morn,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Doth with his lofty and shrill-sounding throat
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Awake the god of day; and, at his warning,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Whether in sea or fire, in earth or air,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: The extravagant and erring spirit hies
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: To his confine: and of the truth herein
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: This present object made probation.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: It faded on the crowing of the cock.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Some say that ever 'gainst that season comes
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: The bird of dawning singeth all night long:
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: And then, they say, no spirit dares stir abroad;
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: The nights are wholesome; then no planets strike,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: No fairy takes, nor witch hath power to charm,
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: So hallow'd and so gracious is the time.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: So have I heard and do in part believe it.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: But, look, the morn, in russet mantle clad,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill:
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Break we our watch up; and by my advice,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Let us impart what we have seen to-night
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: As needful in our loves, fitting our duty?
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Let's do't, I pray; and I this morning know
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: Where we shall find him most conveniently.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother's death
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The memory be green, and that it us befitted
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To bear our hearts in grief and our whole kingdom
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To be contracted in one brow of woe,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Yet so far hath discretion fought with nature
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: That we with wisest sorrow think on him,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Together with remembrance of ourselves.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Therefore our sometime sister, now our queen,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The imperial jointress to this warlike state,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Have we, as 'twere with a defeated joy,--
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: With an auspicious and a dropping eye,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: With mirth in funeral and with dirge in marriage,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: In equal scale weighing delight and dole,--
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Taken to wife: nor have we herein barr'd
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Your better wisdoms, which have freely gone
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: With this affair along. For all, our thanks.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Now follows, that you know, young Fortinbras,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Holding a weak supposal of our worth,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Or thinking by our late dear brother's death
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Our state to be disjoint and out of frame,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Colleagued with the dream of his advantage,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: He hath not fail'd to pester us with message,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Importing the surrender of those lands
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Lost by his father, with all bonds of law,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To our most valiant brother. So much for him.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Now for ourself and for this time of meeting:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Thus much the business is: we have here writ
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras,--
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Who, impotent and bed-rid, scarcely hears
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Of this his nephew's purpose,--to suppress
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: His further gait herein; in that the levies,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The lists and full proportions, are all made
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Out of his subject: and we here dispatch
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: You, good Cornelius, and you, Voltimand,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: For bearers of this greeting to old Norway;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Giving to you no further personal power
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To business with the king, more than the scope
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Of these delated articles allow.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: CORNELIUS
lines.speaker: CORNELIUS

lines.value: VOLTIMAND
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: In that and all things will we show our duty.
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: We doubt it nothing: heartily farewell.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And now, Laertes, what's the news with you?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: You told us of some suit; what is't, Laertes?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: You cannot speak of reason to the Dane,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And loose your voice: what wouldst thou beg, Laertes,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: That shall not be my offer, not thy asking?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The head is not more native to the heart,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The hand more instrumental to the mouth,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Than is the throne of Denmark to thy father.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: What wouldst thou have, Laertes?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LAERTES
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: My dread lord,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Your leave and favour to return to France;
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: From whence though willingly I came to Denmark,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: To show my duty in your coronation,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Yet now, I must confess, that duty done,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: By laboursome petition, and at last
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Upon his will I seal'd my hard consent:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I do beseech you, give him leave to go.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Take thy fair hour, Laertes; time be thine,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And thy best graces spend it at thy will!
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: But now, my cousin Hamlet, and my son,--
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: [Aside]  A little more than kin, and less than kind.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: How is it that the clouds still hang on you?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Not so, my lord; I am too much i' the sun.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Good Hamlet, cast thy nighted colour off,
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Do not for ever with thy vailed lids
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Seek for thy noble father in the dust:
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Thou know'st 'tis common; all that lives must die,
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Passing through nature to eternity.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Ay, madam, it is common.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: If it be,
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Why seems it so particular with thee?
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Seems, madam! nay it is; I know not 'seems.'
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: 'Tis not alone my inky cloak, good mother,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Nor customary suits of solemn black,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Nor windy suspiration of forced breath,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: No, nor the fruitful river in the eye,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Nor the dejected 'havior of the visage,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Together with all forms, moods, shapes of grief,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: That can denote me truly: these indeed seem,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: For they are actions that a man might play:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: But I have that within which passeth show;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: These but the trappings and the suits of woe.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: 'Tis sweet and commendable in your nature, Hamlet,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To give these mourning duties to your father:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: But, you must know, your father lost a father;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: That father lost, lost his, and the survivor bound
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: In filial obligation for some term
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To do obsequious sorrow: but to persever
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: In obstinate condolement is a course
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Of impious stubbornness; 'tis unmanly grief;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: It shows a will most incorrect to heaven,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: A heart unfortified, a mind impatient,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: An understanding simple and unschool'd:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: For what we know must be and is as common
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: As any the most vulgar thing to sense,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Why should we in our peevish opposition
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Take it to heart? Fie! 'tis a fault to heaven,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: A fault against the dead, a fault to nature,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To reason most absurd: whose common theme
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Is death of fathers, and who still hath cried,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: From the first corse till he that died to-day,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: 'This must be so.' We pray you, throw to earth
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: This unprevailing woe, and think of us
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: As of a father: for let the world take note,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: You are the most immediate to our throne;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And with no less nobility of love
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Than that which dearest father bears his son,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Do I impart toward you. For your intent
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: In going back to school in Wittenberg,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: It is most retrograde to our desire:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And we beseech you, bend you to remain
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Here, in the cheer and comfort of our eye,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Our chiefest courtier, cousin, and our son.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Let not thy mother lose her prayers, Hamlet:
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: I pray thee, stay with us; go not to Wittenberg.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I shall in all my best obey you, madam.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Why, 'tis a loving and a fair reply:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Be as ourself in Denmark. Madam, come;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: This gentle and unforced accord of Hamlet
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Sits smiling to my heart: in grace whereof,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: No jocund health that Denmark drinks to-day,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: But the great cannon to the clouds shall tell,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And the king's rouse the heavens all bruit again,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Re-speaking earthly thunder. Come away.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: O, that this too too solid flesh would melt
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Thaw and resolve itself into a dew!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Or that the Everlasting had not fix'd
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: His canon 'gainst self-slaughter! O God! God!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: How weary, stale, flat and unprofitable,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Seem to me all the uses of this world!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Fie on't! ah fie! 'tis an unweeded garden,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: That grows to seed; things rank and gross in nature
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Possess it merely. That it should come to this!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: But two months dead: nay, not so much, not two:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: So excellent a king; that was, to this,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Hyperion to a satyr; so loving to my mother
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: That he might not beteem the winds of heaven
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Visit her face too roughly. Heaven and earth!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Must I remember? why, she would hang on him,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: As if increase of appetite had grown
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: By what it fed on: and yet, within a month--
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Let me not think on't--Frailty, thy name is woman!--
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: A little month, or ere those shoes were old
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: With which she follow'd my poor father's body,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Like Niobe, all tears:--why she, even she--
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: O, God! a beast, that wants discourse of reason,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Would have mourn'd longer--married with my uncle,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: My father's brother, but no more like my father
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Than I to Hercules: within a month:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Had left the flushing in her galled eyes,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: She married. O, most wicked speed, to post
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: With such dexterity to incestuous sheets!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: It is not nor it cannot come to good:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: But break, my heart; for I must hold my tongue.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Hail to your lordship!
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I am glad to see you well:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Horatio,--or I do forget myself.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: The same, my lord, and your poor servant ever.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Sir, my good friend; I'll change that name with you:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: And what make you from Wittenberg, Horatio? Marcellus?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: My good lord--
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I am very glad to see you. Good even, sir.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: But what, in faith, make you from Wittenberg?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: A truant disposition, good my lord.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I would not hear your enemy say so,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Nor shall you do mine ear that violence,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: To make it truster of your own report
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Against yourself: I know you are no truant.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: But what is your affair in Elsinore?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: We'll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: My lord, I came to see your father's funeral.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I pray thee, do not mock me, fellow-student;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I think it was to see my mother's wedding.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Indeed, my lord, it follow'd hard upon.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Thrift, thrift, Horatio! the funeral baked meats
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: My father!--methinks I see my father.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Where, my lord?
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: In my mind's eye, Horatio.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: I saw him once; he was a goodly king.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: He was a man, take him for all in all,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I shall not look upon his like again.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Saw? who?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: My lord, the king your father.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: The king my father!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Season your admiration for awhile
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: With an attent ear, till I may deliver,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Upon the witness of these gentlemen,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: This marvel to you.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: For God's love, let me hear.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Two nights together had these gentlemen,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: In the dead vast and middle of the night,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Been thus encounter'd. A figure like your father,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Armed at point exactly, cap-a-pe,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Appears before them, and with solemn march
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Goes slow and stately by them: thrice he walk'd
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: By their oppress'd and fear-surprised eyes,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Within his truncheon's length; whilst they, distilled
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Almost to jelly with the act of fear,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Stand dumb and speak not to him. This to me
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: In dreadful secrecy impart they did;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And I with them the third night kept the watch;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Where, as they had deliver'd, both in time,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Form of the thing, each word made true and good,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: The apparition comes: I knew your father;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: These hands are not more like.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: But where was this?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: My lord, upon the platform where we watch'd.
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Did you not speak to it?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: My lord, I did;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: But answer made it none: yet once methought
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: It lifted up its head and did address
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Itself to motion, like as it would speak;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: But even then the morning cock crew loud,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And at the sound it shrunk in haste away,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And vanish'd from our sight.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: 'Tis very strange.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: As I do live, my honour'd lord, 'tis true;
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: And we did think it writ down in our duty
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: To let you know of it.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Indeed, indeed, sirs, but this troubles me.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Hold you the watch to-night?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: We do, my lord.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Arm'd, say you?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Arm'd, my lord.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: From top to toe?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: My lord, from head to foot.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Then saw you not his face?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: O, yes, my lord; he wore his beaver up.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: What, look'd he frowningly?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: A countenance more in sorrow than in anger.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Pale or red?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Nay, very pale.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: And fix'd his eyes upon you?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Most constantly.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I would I had been there.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: It would have much amazed you.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Very like, very like. Stay'd it long?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: MARCELLUS
lines.speaker: MARCELLUS

lines.value: BERNARDO
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: Longer, longer.
lines.speaker: BERNARDO

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: Not when I saw't.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: His beard was grizzled--no?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: It was, as I have seen it in his life,
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: A sable silver'd.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I will watch to-night;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Perchance 'twill walk again.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HORATIO
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: I warrant it will.
lines.speaker: HORATIO

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: If it assume my noble father's person,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I'll speak to it, though hell itself should gape
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: And bid me hold my peace. I pray you all,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: If you have hitherto conceal'd this sight,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Let it be tenable in your silence still;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: And whatsoever else shall hap to-night,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Give it an understanding, but no tongue:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I will requite your loves. So, fare you well:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Upon the platform, 'twixt eleven and twelve,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I'll visit you.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: All
lines.speaker: All

lines.value: Our duty to your honour.
lines.speaker: All

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Your loves, as mine to you: farewell.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: My father's spirit in arms! all is not well;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I doubt some foul play: would the night were come!
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Till then sit still, my soul: foul deeds will rise,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men's eyes.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: LAERTES
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: My necessaries are embark'd: farewell:
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And, sister, as the winds give benefit
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And convoy is assistant, do not sleep,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: But let me hear from you.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: OPHELIA
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: Do you doubt that?
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LAERTES
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: For Hamlet and the trifling of his favour,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: A violet in the youth of primy nature,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: The perfume and suppliance of a minute; No more.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: OPHELIA
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: No more but so?
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LAERTES
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Think it no more;
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: For nature, crescent, does not grow alone
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: In thews and bulk, but, as this temple waxes,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: The inward service of the mind and soul
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: The virtue of his will: but you must fear,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: His greatness weigh'd, his will is not his own;
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: For he himself is subject to his birth:
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: He may not, as unvalued persons do,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Carve for himself; for on his choice depends
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: The safety and health of this whole state;
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And therefore must his choice be circumscribed
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Unto the voice and yielding of that body
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: It fits your wisdom so far to believe it
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: As he in his particular act and place
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: May give his saying deed; which is no further
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: If with too credent ear you list his songs,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: To his unmaster'd importunity.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And keep you in the rear of your affection,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Out of the shot and danger of desire.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: The chariest maid is prodigal enough,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: If she unmask her beauty to the moon:
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Virtue itself 'scapes not calumnious strokes:
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: The canker galls the infants of the spring,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Too oft before their buttons be disclosed,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: And in the morn and liquid dew of youth
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Contagious blastments are most imminent.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Be wary then; best safety lies in fear:
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: OPHELIA
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: I shall the effect of this good lesson keep,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: As watchman to my heart. But, good my brother,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: Do not, as some ungracious pastors do,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: Show me the steep and thorny way to heaven;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: Whiles, like a puff'd and reckless libertine,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And recks not his own rede.
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LAERTES
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: O, fear me not.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: I stay too long: but here my father comes.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: A double blessing is a double grace,
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: Occasion smiles upon a second leave.
lines.speaker: LAERTES

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Yet here, Laertes! aboard, aboard, for shame!
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And you are stay'd for. There; my blessing with thee!
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And these few precepts in thy memory
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: See thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Nor any unproportioned thought his act.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Of each new-hatch'd, unfledged comrade. Beware
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Of entrance to a quarrel, but being in,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Bear't that the opposed may beware of thee.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But not express'd in fancy; rich, not gaudy;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: For the apparel oft proclaims the man,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And they in France of the best rank and station
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Are of a most select and generous chief in that.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Neither a borrower nor a lender be;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: For loan oft loses both itself and friend,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: This above all: to thine ownself be true,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And it must follow, as the night the day,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Thou canst not then be false to any man.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Farewell: my blessing season this in thee!
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Ay, springes to catch woodcocks. I do know,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Lends the tongue vows: these blazes, daughter,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Giving more light than heat, extinct in both,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Even in their promise, as it is a-making,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: You must not take for fire. From this time
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Be somewhat scanter of your maiden presence;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Set your entreatments at a higher rate
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Than a command to parley. For Lord Hamlet,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Believe so much in him, that he is young
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And with a larger tether may he walk
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Than may be given you: in few, Ophelia,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Do not believe his vows; for they are brokers,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Not of that dye which their investments show,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But mere implorators of unholy suits,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Breathing like sanctified and pious bawds,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: The better to beguile. This is for all:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I would not, in plain terms, from this time forth,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: As to give words or talk with the Lord Hamlet.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: O wicked wit and gifts, that have the power
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: So to seduce!--won to his shameful lust
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: The will of my most seeming-virtuous queen:
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: O Hamlet, what a falling-off was there!
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: From me, whose love was of that dignity
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: That it went hand in hand even with the vow
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: I made to her in marriage, and to decline
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: To those of mine!
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: But virtue, as it never will be moved,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Though lewdness court it in a shape of heaven,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: So lust, though to a radiant angel link'd,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Will sate itself in a celestial bed,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And prey on garbage.
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: But, soft! methinks I scent the morning air;
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Brief let me be. Sleeping within my orchard,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: My custom always of the afternoon,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Upon my secure hour thy uncle stole,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: With juice of cursed hebenon in a vial,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And in the porches of my ears did pour
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: The leperous distilment; whose effect
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Holds such an enmity with blood of man
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: That swift as quicksilver it courses through
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: The natural gates and alleys of the body,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And with a sudden vigour doth posset
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And curd, like eager droppings into milk,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: The thin and wholesome blood: so did it mine;
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And a most instant tetter bark'd about,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Most lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crust,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: All my smooth body.
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother's hand
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Of life, of crown, of queen, at once dispatch'd:
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Unhousel'd, disappointed, unanel'd,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: No reckoning made, but sent to my account
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: With all my imperfections on my head:
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: O, horrible! O, horrible! most horrible!
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not;
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Let not the royal bed of Denmark be
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: A couch for luxury and damned incest.
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: But, howsoever thou pursuest this act,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Against thy mother aught: leave her to heaven
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And to those thorns that in her bosom lodge,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: To prick and sting her. Fare thee well at once!
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: The glow-worm shows the matin to be near,
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire:
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.value: Adieu, adieu! Hamlet, remember me.
lines.speaker: Ghost

lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: In this distracted globe. Remember thee!

lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Pale as his shirt; his knees knocking each other;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And with a look so piteous in purport
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: As if he had been loosed out of hell
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: To speak of horrors,--he comes before me.
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Mad for thy love?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: OPHELIA
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: My lord, I do not know;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: But truly, I do fear it.
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: What said he?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: OPHELIA
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: He took me by the wrist and held me hard;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: Then goes he to the length of all his arm;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And, with his other hand thus o'er his brow,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: He falls to such perusal of my face
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: As he would draw it. Long stay'd he so;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: At last, a little shaking of mine arm
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And thrice his head thus waving up and down,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: He raised a sigh so piteous and profound
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: As it did seem to shatter all his bulk
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And end his being: that done, he lets me go:
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And, with his head over his shoulder turn'd,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: He seem'd to find his way without his eyes;
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: For out o' doors he went without their helps,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: And, to the last, bended their light on me.
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Come, go with me: I will go seek the king.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: This is the very ecstasy of love,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Whose violent property fordoes itself
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And leads the will to desperate undertakings
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: As oft as any passion under heaven
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That does afflict our natures. I am sorry.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: What, have you given him any hard words of late?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: OPHELIA
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: No, my good lord, but, as you did command,
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: I did repel his fetters and denied
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: His access to me.
lines.speaker: OPHELIA

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That hath made him mad.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I am sorry that with better heed and judgment
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I had not quoted him: I fear'd he did but trifle,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And meant to wreck thee; but, beshrew my jealousy!
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: By heaven, it is as proper to our age
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: As it is common for the younger sort
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: To lack discretion. Come, go we to the king:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: This must be known; which, being kept close, might
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: move
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: More grief to hide than hate to utter love.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern!
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Moreover that we much did long to see you,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The need we have to use you did provoke
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Our hasty sending. Something have you heard
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Of Hamlet's transformation; so call it,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Sith nor the exterior nor the inward man
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Resembles that it was. What it should be,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: More than his father's death, that thus hath put him
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: So much from the understanding of himself,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: I cannot dream of: I entreat you both,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: That, being of so young days brought up with him,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And sith so neighbour'd to his youth and havior,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Some little time: so by your companies
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: So much as from occasion you may glean,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Whether aught, to us unknown, afflicts him thus,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: That, open'd, lies within our remedy.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Good gentlemen, he hath much talk'd of you;
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: And sure I am two men there are not living
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: To whom he more adheres. If it will please you
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: To show us so much gentry and good will
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: As to expend your time with us awhile,
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: For the supply and profit of our hope,
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Your visitation shall receive such thanks
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: As fits a king's remembrance.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: ROSENCRANTZ
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Both your majesties
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Put your dread pleasures more into command
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Than to entreaty.
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: GUILDENSTERN
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: But we both obey,
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: And here give up ourselves, in the full bent
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: To lay our service freely at your feet,
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: To be commanded.
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz:
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: And I beseech you instantly to visit
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: My too much changed son. Go, some of you,
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: GUILDENSTERN
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: Heavens make our presence and our practises
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: Pleasant and helpful to him!
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Ay, amen!
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: The ambassadors from Norway, my good lord,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Are joyfully return'd.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Thou still hast been the father of good news.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Have I, my lord? I assure my good liege,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I hold my duty, as I hold my soul,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Both to my God and to my gracious king:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And I do think, or else this brain of mine
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Hunts not the trail of policy so sure
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: As it hath used to do, that I have found
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: O, speak of that; that do I long to hear.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Give first admittance to the ambassadors;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The head and source of all your son's distemper.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: I doubt it is no other but the main;
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: His father's death, and our o'erhasty marriage.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Well, we shall sift him.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Welcome, my good friends!
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Say, Voltimand, what from our brother Norway?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: VOLTIMAND
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Most fair return of greetings and desires.
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Upon our first, he sent out to suppress
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: His nephew's levies; which to him appear'd
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack;
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: But, better look'd into, he truly found
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: It was against your highness: whereat grieved,
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: That so his sickness, age and impotence
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys;
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Makes vow before his uncle never more
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: To give the assay of arms against your majesty.
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee,
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: And his commission to employ those soldiers,
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: So levied as before, against the Polack:
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: With an entreaty, herein further shown,
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: That it might please you to give quiet pass
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: Through your dominions for this enterprise,
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: On such regards of safety and allowance
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: As therein are set down.
lines.speaker: VOLTIMAND

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: It likes us well;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And at our more consider'd time well read,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Answer, and think upon this business.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Go to your rest; at night we'll feast together:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Most welcome home!
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: This business is well ended.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: My liege, and madam, to expostulate
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: What majesty should be, what duty is,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Why day is day, night night, and time is time,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Were nothing but to waste night, day and time.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I will be brief: your noble son is mad:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Mad call I it; for, to define true madness,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: What is't but to be nothing else but mad?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But let that go.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: More matter, with less art.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Madam, I swear I use no art at all.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That he is mad, 'tis true: 'tis true 'tis pity;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And pity 'tis 'tis true: a foolish figure;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But farewell it, for I will use no art.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Mad let us grant him, then: and now remains
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That we find out the cause of this effect,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Or rather say, the cause of this defect,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: For this effect defective comes by cause:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. Perpend.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I have a daughter--have while she is mine--
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Who, in her duty and obedience, mark,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Hath given me this: now gather, and surmise.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'To the celestial and my soul's idol, the most
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: beautified Ophelia,'--
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase; 'beautified' is
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: a vile phrase: but you shall hear. Thus:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'In her excellent white bosom, these,  & c.'
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: Came this from Hamlet to her?
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Good madam, stay awhile; I will be faithful.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'Doubt thou the stars are fire;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Doubt that the sun doth move;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Doubt truth to be a liar;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But never doubt I love.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I have not art to reckon my groans: but that
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I love thee best, O most best, believe it. Adieu.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'Thine evermore most dear lady, whilst
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: this machine is to him, HAMLET.'
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And more above, hath his solicitings,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: As they fell out by time, by means and place,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: All given to mine ear.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: But how hath she
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Received his love?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: What do you think of me?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: As of a man faithful and honourable.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I would fain prove so. But what might you think,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: When I had seen this hot love on the wing--
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: As I perceived it, I must tell you that,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Before my daughter told me--what might you,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Or my dear majesty your queen here, think,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: If I had play'd the desk or table-book,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Or look'd upon this love with idle sight;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: What might you think? No, I went round to work,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And my young mistress thus I did bespeak:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: This must not be:' and then I precepts gave her,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That she should lock herself from his resort,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Admit no messengers, receive no tokens.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Which done, she took the fruits of my advice;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And he, repulsed--a short tale to make--
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Into the madness wherein now he raves,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And all we mourn for.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Do you think 'tis this?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: It may be, very likely.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Hath there been such a time--I'd fain know that--
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That I have positively said 'Tis so,'
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: When it proved otherwise?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Not that I know.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: [Pointing to his head and shoulder]
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Take this from this, if this be otherwise:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: If circumstances lead me, I will find
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Within the centre.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: How may we try it further?
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: You know, sometimes he walks four hours together
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Here in the lobby.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: So he does indeed.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: At such a time I'll loose my daughter to him:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Be you and I behind an arras then;
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Mark the encounter: if he love her not
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And be not from his reason fall'n thereon,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Let me be no assistant for a state,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: But keep a farm and carters.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: We will try it.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: QUEEN GERTRUDE
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: But, look, where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.
lines.speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Away, I do beseech you, both away:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I'll board him presently.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: O, give me leave:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: How does my good Lord Hamlet?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Well, God-a-mercy.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Do you know me, my lord?
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Excellent well; you are a fishmonger.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Not I, my lord.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Then I would you were so honest a man.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Honest, my lord!
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Ay, sir; to be honest, as this world goes, is to be
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: one man picked out of ten thousand.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: That's very true, my lord.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: god kissing carrion,--Have you a daughter?
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: I have, my lord.
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Let her not walk i' the sun: conception is a
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: blessing: but not as your daughter may conceive.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Friend, look to 't.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HAMLET
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: HAMLET

lines.value: By and by is easily said.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Leave me, friends.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Tis now the very witching time of night,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Contagion to this world: now could I drink hot blood,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: And do such bitter business as the day
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Would quake to look on. Soft! now to my mother.
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: O heart, lose not thy nature; let not ever
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: The soul of Nero enter this firm bosom:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: Let me be cruel, not unnatural:
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: I will speak daggers to her, but use none;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites;
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: How in my words soever she be shent,
lines.speaker: HAMLET

lines.value: To give them seals never, my soul, consent!

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: I like him not, nor stands it safe with us
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: To let his madness range. Therefore prepare you;
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: I your commission will forthwith dispatch,
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: And he to England shall along with you:
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: The terms of our estate may not endure
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: Out of his lunacies.
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: GUILDENSTERN
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: We will ourselves provide:
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: Most holy and religious fear it is
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: To keep those many many bodies safe
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: That live and feed upon your majesty.
lines.speaker: GUILDENSTERN

lines.value: ROSENCRANTZ
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: The single and peculiar life is bound,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: With all the strength and armour of the mind,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: To keep itself from noyance; but much more
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: That spirit upon whose weal depend and rest
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: The lives of many. The cease of majesty
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Dies not alone; but, like a gulf, doth draw
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: What's near it with it: it is a massy wheel,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Fix'd on the summit of the highest mount,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Are mortised and adjoin'd; which, when it falls,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Each small annexment, petty consequence,
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Attends the boisterous ruin. Never alone
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: Did the king sigh, but with a general groan.
lines.speaker: ROSENCRANTZ

lines.value: KING CLAUDIUS
lines.speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

lines.value: LORD POLONIUS

lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: And, as you said, and wisely was it said,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: 'Tis meet that some more audience than a mother,
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: Since nature makes them partial, should o'erhear
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS

lines.value: The speech, of vantage. Fare you well, my liege:
lines.speaker: LORD POLONIUS
